title: 109_hr67
content: The "National Commission on the Modernization of the United Nations Act of 2005" establishes a commission with duties to modernize the United Nations. The Commission established by the "National Commission on the Modernization of the United Nations Act of 2005" is tasked with conducting studies, recommending reforms, and enumerating methods for implementing changes to the organizational structure and practices of the United Nations. This includes studying the extent of modernization within the current Charter without substantive changes, as well as identifying areas that may require modifications to the Charter for modernization. The United Nations modernization requires substantive changes to the Charter, focusing on Member State Principles such as adherence to UN values, response to Charter violations, and defining unacceptable conduct. Recommendations for modernization implementation are also essential. The Commission will study the feasibility of requiring member states to regularly review their adherence to UN principles and sign a declaration agreeing to uphold them. The Commission will study whether the United Nations should withdraw from membership if it is not adhering to the Charter. Additionally, it will examine proportional representation in the General Assembly, the structure of the UN, funding for auxiliary commissions, and whether these organizations detract from the UN's primary functions. The Commission will study the use, structure, and goals of peacekeeping and humanitarian efforts, including whether a separate peacekeeping force should be maintained and the successes of past efforts. It will also examine the enforcement of resolutions and the credibility of mandates when absolute obedience is not mandated by the United Nations. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of nine members appointed by various officials, excluding government officers or employees. Each member serves for the duration of the Commission and cannot continue if they join the government. The Commission consists of nine members appointed by officials, excluding government employees. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairperson is elected by members after consultation with key leaders. Members receive travel expenses as per federal regulations. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR AND STAFF. The Commission appoints a Director paid at level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director can hire staff under certain conditions and follow civil service laws. Federal agencies can provide staff upon request. The head of any Federal department or agency may detail personnel to the Commission on a reimbursable basis for assistance. The Administrator of General Services shall provide administrative support services to the Commission upon request. SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission shall meet at the call of the Chairperson. A majority of members shall constitute a quorum. The Commission may obtain necessary information from US departments or agencies. It can use the US mails. SEC. 7. REPORTS. SEC. 7. REPORTS. The Commission must submit an interim report to Congress within six months and a final report within 12 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 8. TERMINATION. The Commission will end 15 days after submitting its final report. SEC. 9. DEFINITIONS. Definitions include "Charter" as the UN Charter, "Commission" as the National Commission on the Modernization of the UN, and "member" as a Commission member.
